key_points: The Department of Energy requests $201 million from Congress for cybersecurity in its fiscal 2022 budget, up from $157 million in 2021.
The additional funding is aimed at bolstering cybersecurity efforts, addressing supply chain and tech infrastructure gaps.
Secretary of Energy Jennifer Granholm highlighted the need for upgrading software and hiring more cybersecurity professionals.
Granholm pointed out the absence of cyber standards in the pipeline industry, as made evident by the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack.
The Biden administration is considering ways to improve private sector collaboration with the government on cybersecurity.
Granholm criticized the status quo and suggested the government might need more visibility into private sector systems.
The federal civilian cybersecurity budget request for 2022 is $9.8 billion, a nearly 15% increase from 2021.
The Pentagon's cybersecurity budget request for 2022 is $10.4 billion.
The request follows a series of ransomware attacks affecting Americans and disrupting services.
The U.S. officially blamed Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service for the SolarWinds cyberattack, which Russia denies.
